Articles.Content: I'm just curious if anyone else knew about this. Your camera POV moves. If this is some old feature I never realized existed, just quietly let this thread die. Otherwise, I hope learns from it.

Arguably even cooler: in the new mk1 cockpit double click the "docking mode" monitor and it will flip you to a station in the back of the pod with another nav ball and a window to use while docking spaceplanes.
It's an old feature, but I think they added some spots where you could do this.

Yeah OP, that feature has been around a long time. When you've double clicked on a window; a)single clicking will lock your view, stop you panning about and you can use mouse-wheel to zoom.
That is cool. Maybe more people would know about this with some kind of, oh, I don't know... Documentation. Just an idea Squad... I'm not married to it.

There's an even cooler feature where double clicking the black space between the mk2 windows (while in IVA) (where the dash meets the front) your view flip 180 degrees so your in IVA mode but your looking backwards or otherwise RETROGRADE. Don't know how useful this is outside of cinimatics, but is cool.

I understand your frustration completely with those who want a mindless game. KSP is NOT the game for those who do not wish to:

  • Have patience and the ability to understand that failure is always an option.
  • Learn about physics.
  • Learn that sometimes the biggest craft or creation is not always the best.
  • Understand that "KISS" (Keep it simple, stupid!) is an acronym that can also be applied to KSP.
  • Learn how to plan a mission and design a craft to perform the required tasks on that mission.
  • Understand that the true reward of KSP is getting the data you needed while not killing your crew.
  • Have fun thinking outside the box.

Also, sarcasm is almost every American's second nature. We are sarcastic about everything; for this reason I added the at the end of my statement as an indicator that I was being sarcastic. Another thing to remember about Americans is that we have the "I don't need no instructions" gene in our DNA. Let's just say that a few fried mother boards in the 1980s, along with reminder lessons in the '90s, ("hey, where did these extra parts come from") AND putting together a lot of plastic model kits as a youth taught me to ALWAYS READ THE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST.

So, with that said, no need to apologize for life is good! Cheers.
